historySlides.text: The new millennium is an era of innovation. Solid-core balls and thin-faced, oversized drivers quickly dominate the market. Rigorous training methods and new swing techniques emerge. Clubhead speeds increase and driving distances surge. To the delight of many fans, golf is now a power game.
historySlides.title: A New Game for a New Century

historySlides.text: Tiger Woods bursts onto the scene with a stunning victory in the 1997 Masters. With power and charisma, he transforms the game. Annika Sorenstam is the new face of women’s golf, a rival to Woods for star power and fan appeal. Moreover, she is a savvy business woman, who parlays her success into an internationally recognized brand.
historySlides.title: New Stars Take The Golf World by Storm

historySlides.text: International talent floods the PGA TOUR and LPGA Tour. Foreign-born players claim major championship titles in record numbers. Following her victory in the 1998 U.S. Women’s Open, Se Ri Pak inspires an entire generation of Korean youth to take up golf, changing the face and trajectory of the LPGA Tour.
historySlides.title: Global Talent Transforms the Tours

historySlides.text: Golf’s leading organizations launch initiatives to the grow the game. The First Tee quickly expands to 200 chapters and 2,000 schools across 48 states and four international locations. For the first time, the U.S. Open is played on a public golf course — Long Island’s Bethpage Black in 2002.
historySlides.title: Golf Reaches Out

historySlides.text: In the face of resource constraints and rising costs, golf course superintendents, owners and operators embrace best practice to reduce the resource footprints of golf courses. New golf course designs embrace minimalism, environmental best practices, and sustainable varieties of turf grass to reduce labor, water, nutrient and chemical consumption.
historySlides.title: A Greener Game

eras_by_id.title: The New Millenium
eras_by_id.description: The brightest lights define a vibrant future for the game

profiles.bioText:
Phil Mickelson, whose remarkable collegiate and amateur careers foreshadowed great professional success, won 45 events, including six majors, in 30 years on the PGA TOUR. A four-time All American at Arizona State, Mickelson won the NCAA title and U.S. Amateur in 1990, following Jack Nicklaus as the second to claim the two prestigious events in one year. Mickelson captured his first PGA TOUR title at the 1991 Northern Telecom Open during his junior year, becoming the second player since 1954 to win a TOUR event as an amateur.

History’s most accomplished left-handed golfer also become the oldest major champion with his victory at the 2021 PGA Championship at age 50. Mickelson remained in the top 50 of the Official World Golf Rankings for 25 consecutive years.
profiles.quote: The object of golf is not just to win. It is to play like a gentleman, and win.

profiles.bioText:
Considered by many the greatest woman golfer of all time, eight-time Player of the Year Annika Sorenstam secured 72 LPGA titles between 1995 and 2008, including 10 major championships.

During the second round of the 2001 Standard Register PING, Sorenstam shot 13-under par to record the first 59 in LPGA history. Two years later, at the Bank of America Colonial, she became the first woman to play on the PGA TOUR since Babe Zaharias in 1945. Later in 2003, she became just the sixth woman to complete the LPGA career Grand Slam. 

Sorenstam, who played on eight Solheim Cup teams for Europe from 1994 to 2007, is tied with Laura Davies for most matches won (22) and served as team captain in 2017.
profiles.quote: To play well you have to have good balance in your life. If you play golf long enough you'll learn that life is more than golf.

profiles.bioText:
Teen sensation Karrie Webb spent little time competing as an amateur, turning professional at age 19 and heading off to play in Europe and the United States. In 1996, her rookie year, she won four times on the LGPA Tour, becoming the first to win more than $1 million in a single season. She would go on to claim 41 LPGA tournaments, including seven major championships.

With her victory in the 2001 LPGA Championship, Webb became the LPGA’s youngest career Grand Slam winner at age 26. With her win at the 2002 Women's British Open, she earned a Career Super Slam, having won all the majors titles available at that time on the LPGA Tour.
profiles.quote: The beauty of golf is one day I love it, the next day I hate it. But no matter how my day goes on the course, I get up and I do it again.

profiles.bioText:
Se Ri Pak, the first Korean member of the World Golf Hall of Fame, won 25 events on the LPGA Tour, including five major championships. She found success quickly, winning four times in 1998 to earn Rolex Rookie of the Year honors. The highlight of her year came at Blackwolf Run in Wisconsin, where her she became the youngest winner to date in U.S. Women’s Open history. 

During her career, Pak went 5-0 in playoffs, made 29 consecutive cuts in major championships and claimed the 2003 Vare Trophy for the lowest scoring average. She retired from competitive golf in 2016, but her greatest legacy remains the entire generation of female golfers she inspired in her South Korea.
profiles.quote: Se Ri is just like Tiger is to every American kid. We all wanted to be her.
profiles.quoteByline: Birdie Kim, 2005 U.S. Women's Open Champion

profiles.bioText:
Lorena Ochoa Reyes won 27 events, including consecutive major titles at the 2007 Ricoh British Open and 2008 Kraft Nabisco Championship, in just seven years on the LPGA Tour.

While attending the University of Arizona, Ochoa Reyes won 12 collegiate tournaments and earned the 2001 NCAA Player and Freshman of the Year awards. Her breakthrough year as a professional came in 2006 ,when she won six tournaments and earned the LPGA Tour Player of the Year and Vare Trophy for the lowest scoring average, honors she held for four consecutive years. 

After 158 weeks atop the Official World Golf Ranking, Ochoa Reyes announced her retirement from competitive golf in 2010 to focus on her foundation in Mexico and begin raising a family.
profiles.quote: I hit a lot of bad shots, but you just need to laugh about them, be able to have a smile on your face, and just keep moving.

profiles.bioText:
Ernie Els, nicknamed “The Big Easy” for his fluid, powerful swing, captured more than 70 professional tournaments worldwide, including four major championships. He demonstrated great potential from a young age, winning the Junior World Golf Championship's 13-14-year-old division in 1984. With his victories in the 1994 and 1997 U.S. Open and 2002 and 2012 Open Championship, Els became just the eighth player to win a major championship in three different decades.

Els led the European Tour Order of Merit in 2003 and 2004 and in 2014 became the first to surpass €30 million in career earnings on the European Tour. He played on eight International Teams in the Presidents Cup from 1996 to 2011.
profiles.quote: If you don't believe you can make every putt, why bother trying?

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the New Millennium Vijay Singh

profiles.bioText:
Vijay Singh, the most extraordinary golfing talent produced by the island nation of Fiji, claimed 34 titles on the PGA TOUR, including the 1998 and 2004 PGA Championship and the 2000 Masters. He joined the PGA TOUR in 1993 and won the Buick Classic the same year, which helped secure Rookie of the Year honors. 

Singh’s 2004 season was the best of his career, as he became the first player to surpass $10 million in official earnings in a single season. He won nine times that year, recorded 18 top-ten finishes and was named the PGA TOUR and PGA Of America Player of the Year.

Singh was named to the International Team for the Presidents Cup eight times between 1994 and 2009.
profiles.quote: If I can hit the ball the way I want to hit it on the range, I'd rather do that than play golf. I just love the feeling of hitting good golf shots.

profiles.bioText:
Stuck by lightning while playing golf at age 15, Retief Goosen leveraged his calm demeanor to claim the U.S. Open in 2001 and 2004. He remained in the top ten of the Official World Golf Ranking for 250 weeks from 2001 to 2008, won more than 30 times worldwide and headed the European Tour Order of Merit in 2001 and 2002.

Goosen represented South Africa in five World Cup events, winning in 2001 with Ernie Els as his teammate. He also played on six international Presidents Cup teams between 2000 and 2011. 

Goosen was named Rookie of the Year on PGA TOUR Champions in 2019, notching a victory in the Bridgestone Senior Players Championship.
profiles.quote: Golf is feel. You can look at all the top players in the world through the decades, the legends of the game, and all their swings are different because they learnt how to swing and feel their swing.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the New Millennium Billy Payne

profiles.bioText:
A standout All-American football player at the University of Georgia in the 1960s, William Porter “Billy” Payne first gained international prominence for spearheading the effort to bring the 1996 Summer Olympic Games to Atlanta as the head of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games.

During his tenure as the Chairman of Augusta National Golf Club from 2006 to 2017, Payne expanded club membership to women and ushered in a new era for the sport by expanding access for young people around the world. He helped start the Drive, Chip and Putt Championship for children ages 7-15 and helped create two new events, the Latin America Amateur Championship and the Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship.
profiles.quote: Professionals have to a large degree been heroes. We want to establish a grassroots program so that kids could be excited by seeing one of their own.
profiles.quoteByline: Billy Payne, on the inspiration for Drive, Chip, and Putt

profiles.bioText:
Dennis Walters won the New Jersey Junior Championship, Caddie Championship and Public Links Junior Championship in 1967. After attending North Texas University, he competed on the South African Tour with the goal of eventually qualifying for the PGA TOUR.

However, tragedy struck on July 21, 1974, when Walters was thrown from a golf cart and left paralyzed from the waist down. True to his favorite expression, Walters “found a new dream” and learned to play from a modified golf cart. Over the next forty-five years, “The Dennis Walters Golf Show” traveled more three-and-a-half million miles and made more than 3,000 appearances where Walters performed trick shots. He won the seated division of the inaugural U.S. Adaptive Open at Pinehurst in 2022.
profiles.quote: If you have a dream and it doesn't work out, never stop dreaming! Get a new dream!
